Let $\vartheta(n)$ be the Chebyshev function
$$\vartheta(n)=\sum_{\substack{p\le n\\p{\:\mathrm{prime}}}} \log p.$$
Then $\vartheta(n)\le n\log 4$ for all $n\ge 1$.

By induction.

The cases for $n=1$ and $n=2$ follow by inspection.

For even $n>2$, the case follows immediately from the case for $n-1$
since $n$ is not prime.

So let $n=2m+1$ with $m>0$ and consider $(1+1)^{2m+1}$ and its . Since
$\displaystyle {{2m+1}\choose m}={{2m+1}\choose{m+1}}$ and each term
occurs exactly once, it follows that
$\displaystyle {{2m+1}\choose m}\leq 4^m$. Each prime $p$ with
$m+1<p\leq 2m+1$ divides ${2m+1}\choose m$, implying that their product
also divides $\displaystyle {{2m+1}\choose m}$. Hence
$$\vartheta(2m+1)-\vartheta(m+1)\le\log{{2m+1}\choose m}\le m\log 4.$$
By the induction hypothesis, $\vartheta(m+1)\leq(m+1)\log4$ and so
$\vartheta(2m+1)\leq(2m+1)\log4$.
